channel.title: Rendering 10-30K Entities
channel.description: Lets say i have 10-30k entities to render(client), all had to be rendered then stored for further use(aside from the static game objects), like players and npcs would be better to use queue, set, or a object array?

item.title: Rendering 10-30K Entities
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Moparisthebest:

It is NOT faster to ‘go backwards because you only access players.length once’, because the compiler (again, way smarter than you) caches what players.length returns (it knows it is static and doesn’t change, so it only calls it once) and therefore calls it only once.

Additionally it might be able to unroll the loop. It is much more likely to do that if you loop forwards since most people go forwards.

Read full topic

item.title: Rendering 10-30K Entities
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Killer-99-pkz, post:16, topic:300372”]for (int n = players.length - 1; n != -1; n++)
if (players[n].id == reqid)
return players[n];

Why go backwards? because you only have to access players.length once…[/quote]

I would like to address this once quickly. There is one thing you have to learn in computer science, the people who write compilers for a living are far smarter than you have ever thought about being. It is a bad (and wrong) assumption that you are smarter than the compiler, you are not, this code being a case in point.

It is NOT faster to ‘go backwards because you only access players.length once’, because the compiler (again, way smarter than you) caches what players.length returns (it knows it is static and doesn’t change, so it only calls it once) and therefore calls it only once.

If you really want to optimize your code and save 5ms over 100,000 iterations, when you use n++ like that it is slower than ++n because n++ has to copy the value to a new register, use the old register for the return value, increment the new one, and then update any pointers. Where as ++n just increments the value in place. However, this is a case in which the compiler will probably optimize this for you again.

Read full topic

[/quote]
but if i don’t want that code in there, and its ME programming with it, shouldn’t it be my decision whether to use it or not?[/quote]
how is it not your choice? its giving you everything you need, you use whatever parts of it you want

gj being ignorant

item.title: Rendering 10-30K Entities
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“light232, post:27, topic:300372”][quote author=zstars link=topic=396652.msg2948146#msg2948146 date=1252338049]
I don’t see a problem with JME being large either. Unless the Java VM happens to suck particularly bad, unused code won’t affect performance.
[/quote]
but if i don’t want that code in there, and its ME programming with it, shouldn’t it be my decision whether to use it or not?[/quote]

Use and presence are different concepts. I doubt you use every single Java class in the Java standard library on every project and yet they are there. And unless the JVM is poorly designed their presence should only have a negligible hard disk memory cost but no performance cost.

Read full topic

sorry jME is shit, i would rather use jPCT, however i dont want to use any of those, id rather learn myself
[/quote]I like how you’re asking questions about optimising performance for a game, then go and call jME shit. Maybe when you used it, your code wasn’t any good. It would make sense. Although the more likely option is that you’ve never fuckin’ used it and you’re going on hearsay. I also never told you to jME I told you to look at it to learn about it’s scene-graph architecture. Fucking idiot.

um, its my opinion about jME…and i dont like it, is there anything wrong with that?

they dont use accessor methods, they go directly to the field. using accessor methods is pointless in this kind of situation…

for (int n = players.length - 1; n != -1; n++)
if (players[n].id == reqid)
return players[n];

Why go backwards? because you only have to access players.length once… why not use accessor methods? because its pointless and just slows your logic down. and i bet that the id is stored on the freaking array as the player id IE: player[ID]… cant you people think logicly instead of stupidly?
[/quote]You should fucking learn to conventions moron. Ps, l2spell

Also, light232, what is it you don’t like about jME?

its too heavy-weight, jPCT on the other hand is lightweight and alot faster
[/quote]The whole purpose of jME is to be heavyweight… it aims to be a complete api for game programming.

and that is its downfall
it has so much code, for every type of game…and most of that is not needed for just one project
http://jmonkeyengine.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/src/com/jme/system/jogl/
for example, its shit
[/quote]It fills it’s purposes perfectly.[/quote]
did u take a look at the code or are you just saying that?
cuz if so then idk whats wrong with your eyes

item.title: Rendering 10-30K Entities
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“Killer-99-pkz, post:16, topic:300372”]they dont use accessor methods, they go directly to the field. using accessor methods is pointless in this kind of situation…

for (int n = players.length - 1; n != -1; n++)
if (players[n].id == reqid)
return players[n];

Why go backwards? because you only have to access players.length once… why not use accessor methods? because its pointless and just slows your logic down. and i bet that the id is stored on the freaking array as the player id IE: player[ID]… cant you people think logicly instead of stupidly?[/quote]

Not sure who you are replying to as I don’t think anybody made any emphasis on accessor methods or suggested any particularly stupid solution, but assuming you are using that loop to look for a requested id, as you seem to be doing, it is not a good approach from an algorithmic perspective.

A brute force algorithm such as that is O(n) and in the case of the 30000 entities would need to perform by average 15000 operations before it finds the right player. Also, that approach assumes IDs are perfectly sequential at any given moment of time, which is often incovenient.

On the other side, a binary tree (O(logn)) would take by average 15 operations (versus 15000) to find the player.

A hash map (O(1)) would take by average a single operation to find it.

Note that this would also apply for spatial queries. Obtaining players-in-range lists for every player through a brute force algorithm would be O(n^2) whereas with an structure such as a quadtree it would be O(n logn).

For 30000 entities, this is 900,000,000 operations versus 446,181.

Read full topic

item.title: Rendering 10-30K Entities
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

It depends on your specific needs. However, generally you will want to store references to the entities on a hash map, sorted by their ID, so that ID queries can be done efficiently and with O(1) complexity. As frank said, you will also want to use some sort of scene graph. There are several alternatives, and depending on the game and other factors some may be more efficient than others. Some popular ones are: BSP trees, quadtrees, kd-trees, octrees, spheretrees, speedtrees. Most trees will allow logarithmic spatial queries in the average case ( O(log(n)) ). Depending again on the circumstances, sometimes two different structures are used, one optimized for static objects and another for dynamic objects (For example, a PR-tree for static and a point auto-balanced quadtree for dynamic).

Read full topic
